 Our app is about guide for pc builds, and some recommended packagees
that fits your budget while looking for some hot af gaming rigs that
can burn your pockets and leave you in debt. Let's Get Started
Fill up the Information below. Full Name Email Password Confirm Password Register What do you want to do? Hello blank fragment Welcome to the guiding window where we have provided you a step-by-step tutorial oh building a PC. Welcome to the guiding window where we have provided you a step-by-step tutorial on choosing a PC parts. Step 1
(Preparation) Step 2
(Installing CPU) Step 3
(Installing RAM) Step 4
(Installing Motherboard) Step 5
(Installing Power Supply) Step 6
(Installing SSD) Step 7
(Installing GPU) " Make sure you have all the necessary hardware components for your build, including the CPU, motherboard, RAM, graphics card, storage drives, power supply, and any additional peripherals you want to install." " Ensure that all your components are compatible with each other and fit within your chosen PC case. Verify that the CPU socket matches the motherboard, the RAM is compatible, and the power supply provides enough wattage for your components." " Before you touch the CPU, ground yourself by wearing the anti-static wristband or by touching a grounded metal surface to discharge any static electricity." " Make sure the Intel CPU must go to the Intel Motherboards(B460, B560, and Z590). And it also depends what DDR your motherboard is. So does in the AMD CPU in AMD Motherboards(B450, B550, B560, and X570)" " On your motherboard, identify the RAM slots. These are usually long, rectangular slots grouped together near the CPU socket. Gently insert the RAM module into the slot at a slight angle, then press down evenly on both ends until the retention clips click into place." " Also, make sure to know if your Motherboard is DDR3, DDR4 or DDR5. Because the most important part of this tutorial is the compatibility of your PC Parts." " Once the motherboard is in place, use the provided screws (usually included with the case or motherboard) to secure it to the standoffs. Start by loosely screwing in each corner screw, and then gradually tighten them in a crisscross pattern to ensure even pressure. Be careful not to overtighten, as this can damage the motherboard." " Check your Motherboard's Size. And ATX case can fit all of the sizes of the Motherboards. An mATX can only fit mATX and ITX motherboards. And ITX motherboards are the smallest." " Place the PSU in the designated area with the fan facing downward (if your case has a PSU shroud with ventilation) or upward, depending on your case's design and airflow requirements. The PSU fan should face the inside of the case to help expel hot air." " A PSU or Power Supply Unit is the hardest to trust if it is rated or not. Because some brands of the PSU is not 80+ certified, or some say it is True Rated. The brand I suggest is Corsair, Seasonic, Coolermaster and FSP." " For SATA SSDs, connect one end of the SATA data cable to the SSD and the other end to an available SATA port on the motherboard. Attach the SSD to the drive bay using screws. In many cases, there are mounting holes for securing the SSD in place. All Storages are Compatible." " For NVMe SSDs (M.2 SSDs), gently insert the NVMe SSD into the M.2 slot at a slight angle (about 30â€“45 degrees) and then press it down until it's seated firmly. It will fasten in place with a screw. Once the NVMe SSD is securely installed, close the case and secure it with screws." " Align the graphics card with the PCIe slot. Carefully insert it into the slot. Make sure it's properly seated and that the PCIe connector at the bottom of the card fits securely into the slot. You may need to gently press down until it clicks into place. Attach the graphics card to the case using screws. The case should have corresponding holes and mounting points. Tighten the screws to secure the card in place. Be careful not to overtighten." " Ensure that the graphics card is recognized and working correctly. You can do this by checking your system information or running a graphics-intensive application or game. And congratulations, you built up your first system unit! Keep Calm and Enjoy to play the game!"
\headings for the slide screen Welcome to PCHub
for Dummies Easy access in your pocket Assembly Guides and Recommendations Computer Parts Let's get started! \Description part of the headings i think App that can show pc assembly guide and recommended pc parts which you can buy on our app! Convenient app that can fit in your pocket! Guides and Recommendation that you can check out Login or Create your own account to get started!
" Here is where we will give you guidance in choosing parts for your PC build and give you some of out recommendation parts and why do we recommend them. Should you pick AMD or Intel What type of motherboard should you pick? What to know about graphics cards and should you buy one? Pick the correct Power Supply Unit. Type of SSD and which one should you buy? How many capacity and Hz of RAM should you pick? What casing and what size suites your taste?
" AMD vs Intel. One of the most controversial battles between manufacturers of CPU." " But which manufacturer offers better quality, performance, features and price? Let this guide break it down for you." " To make things short and simple, both manufacturer's products may vary depending on their offered features and what suits your preference." " To see their difference, if you are building a PC where you can play light games on it or doing heavy multitasking workloads, and consumes less power, then AMD is the choice for you. Which is why majority of consumers use AMD because it is cheaper and meets the consumer's common level of standards." " And if you are looking for a CPU for your PC build where you can play and run high-frequency games and video applications. Intel would be a better choice for you because they have more cores and faster memory access speeds than their AMD counterparts. " "After picking a side, you must consider these things before buying a CPU: 
Compatibility with Motherboard - Ensure that the CPU you are considering is compatible with your motherboard's. 
Performance - Consider the CPU's performance in terms of clock speed (GHz), the number of cores, and the number of threads. 
Intended Use - If you're building a gaming PC, look for a CPU with strong single-core performance. For content creation or multitasking, consider CPUs with more cores and threads. 
Budget - While there are high-end CPUs with cutting-edge features, there are also budget-friendly options that can provide good performance for everyday tasks. 
Cooling Requirements - Some CPUs come with a stock cooler or an aftermarket cooler. 
Overclocking - This is optional. If you're interested in overclocking or maximizing your CPU for additional performance, look for an unlocked CPU (often denoted with a "K" for Intel or "X" for AMD) and ensure your motherboard supports overclocking. 
TDP (Thermal Design Power) - Check the TDP of the CPU to make sure it's within the thermal limits your cooling solution and motherboard can handle. 
Reviews and Benchmarks - Read reviews and look for benchmark and some Real-World performance tests results for the specific CPU models you're interested in. 
Power Efficiency - If energy efficiency is important to you, look for CPUs with low power consumption. 
Integrated Graphics - Some CPUs come with integrated graphics, which can be handy if you don't plan to use a dedicated graphics card 
Upgrade Path - Consider whether the CPU you're buying allows for future upgrades on the same motherboard, as this can save you money in the long run."
" So have you decided what CPU are you going to pick?" " Is it gonna be an AMD or an Intel? Check out our shop for some "
